channel.title: New Orleans Louisiana on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content in New Orleans Louisiana on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: Obituary: Greg Peters, 50; Louisiana political cartoonist
item.description:
An obituary for Greg Peters is in Gambit, a New Orleans publication that he contributed political cartoons to. I knew him from high school in Marquette (from debate and High School Bowl) and hadn't stayed in touch for years, so this was a bit of a shock.
Bottom, from left: Tom Baldini (coach), me (alternate), Greg Peters, Joel White, Kerry Johnson, Mike Coyne, David Goldsmith (host). "Nothing you learn is ever wasted.

item.title: Michigan vs Virginia Tech (Hoke vs Hokies) in Sugar Bowl, January 3, 2012 in New Orleans; also, sandwiches
item.description: Follow the coverage from all sides. National coverage: ESPN's WolverineNation coverage from beat writer Michael Rothstein. Michigan Wolverines Land Sugar Bowl. It almost didn't happen, however. After finishing the regular season 10-2, the Wolverines needed help from other teams around the country on Saturday and from the pollsters on Sunday morning in order to be in this position -- and they received it. On Virginia Tech, the Washington Post writes "

item.title: Obituary: Jeff Lamb, photographer of New Orleans, Detroit, Ann Arbor and the Leelenau Peninsula
item.description: Jeff Lamb (January 16, 1949 - March 22, 2011) was a photographer of New Orleans, Detroit, Ann Arbor and the Leelenau Peninsula. He is survived by his wife, Leyla Lau-Lamb, his dog, Sonny, and other relations and many friends. There will be a celebration of Jeff's life at Hathaway's Hideaway, 310 S. Ashley, Ann Arbor, on Saturday, April 9th beginning at 4:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Advocacy Department of the Preservation Resource Center of New Orleans.

item.title: Building Mississippi cottages, tearing down New Orleans houses
item.description: The Christian Science Monitor has a good story with pictures of the current state of the "Mississippi Cottage" design of manufactured housing. Hurricane Katrina downsized his domain to nothing. Today, his new castle is about one-seventh the size of his old one, measuring 450 square feet. But surveying the familiar view from the dollhouse porch of his “Mississippi cottage,” Mr. Voorhies is one of many storm survivors who have reassessed their coastal existence.
